items.title: SARS-CoV-2 within-host population expansion, diversification and adaptation in zoo tigers, lions and hyenas
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66402-7 This paper describes within-host evolutionary dynamics of SARS-CoV-2 during an outbreak in three carnivore species. Positive selection and the emergence of potentially species-specific mutations were observed in lion and hyena samples.

items.title: Shell-isolated nanoparticle-enhanced femtosecond stimulated Raman spectroscopy reveals ultrafast molecular dynamics of surface reactions
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66454-9 Shell-isolated nanoparticle enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SHINERS) has enhanced the sensitivity of Raman spectroscopy for applications in materials and life sciences. Here, the authors develop its femtosecond stimulated version (SHINE-FSRS) for in-situ monitoring of molecular dynamics on ultrafast scales.

items.title: Why covalent organic frameworks grow twisted on graphite
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67598-4 Van der Waals two dimensional materials made of graphene and covalent organic frameworks have potential for advanced electronics applications and a fundamental understanding of the formation process of these materials is desirable. Here, the authors revealed the main aspects that influence the twisted stacking growth of pyrene diboronic acid covalent organic frameworks on graphite with a hybrid molecular mechanics force field.

items.title: Direct observations of cross-scale energy transfer driven by multiple-ion interactions in space plasmas
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66374-8 The study provides observational evidence of energy transfer in space plasmas, showing hydrogen and helium ions interact differently with ion-scale waves. Despite helium’s low abundance, they show their interaction can excite electrostatic waves, facilitating energy transfer across scales and challenging traditional models.

items.title: Targeted CRISPR-Cas9 screening identifies core transcription factors controlling murine haemato-endothelial fate commitment
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66230-9 During development, blood is generated in the yolk sac by differentiation of haemato-endothelial mesoderm into haematopoietic progenitors. Using CRISPR-Cas9 screens, the authors identify Etv2, Smad1, Ldb1, Six4 and Zbtb7b as regulators of haemato-endothelial mesoderm commitment. Lack of these regulators gave rise to mesodermal subsets with a defined lineage differentiation bias.

items.title: Prevotella copri promotes white adipose browning and ameliorates adiposity
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67327-x The gut microbiome can regulate diverse host metabolic processes, including thermogenesis in adipose tissues. Here, the authors report a reduced abundance of Prevotella copri in patients with obesity and its role in alleviating adiposity.

items.title: Photoelectrochemical water splitting cells at elevated pressure using BiVO<sub>4</sub> and platinized III-V semiconductor photoelectrodes
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67294-3 Many hydrogen applications require gas delivered under pressure. Here, the authors report that solar water-splitting devices can operate at up to 8 bar and show that the performance gains from elevated pressure depends critically on the choice of materials and device configuration.

items.title: Thermal responsive Rh<sub>1</sub>-Pd single-atom catalyst for controlling activity in direct formic acid fuel cells
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66532-y Thermal protection is critical to extend the service life and avoid overheating in electrochemical devices. Here, the authors report a thermosensitive single-atom Rh1-Pd electrode that enables high activity towards formic acid electrooxidation under 35 °C, which drop down when the temperature is over 35 °C.

This Colloquium describes the methodology for such a test and presents its outcome based on the analysis of recent large catalogs of radio galaxies and quasars, revealing a significant inconsistency between the two dipoles. The authors review these recent findings, as well as potential biases, systematic issues, and alternate interpretations, and discuss how this anomaly could challenge the standard description of our Universe based on the Λ CDM model. items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03806-x Perovskites are promising materials for solar cells. A layer of dipolar molecules at the perovskite surface improves the efficiency of these devices.

items.title: A super-conducting diode with ultimate efficiency and noise resilience at 77 K
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03118-x An electrical method is shown to reliably introduce nonreciprocal behaviour across a Josephson junction made of high-temperature cuprate superconductors, which then, under microwave irradiation, forms a ‘quantum superconducting diode’. The device is magnetic-field-free, works at a temperature of 77 K with a diode efficiency of 100%, and, owing to Shapiro steps that quantize the output voltage, has robust noise-filtering.
